questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not typically associated with the histopathological feature shown below?
questions.solution:
The above histopathological slide shows a Psammoma body. It is not typically seen in follicular carcinoma of the thyroid.

Psammoma bodies are are concentric, lamellated structures formed as a product of dystrophic calcification. They are associated with papillary histomorphology and are caused by infarction and calcification of papillae tips. 

Conditions associated with psammoma bodies include-

  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma
  • Papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary
  • Papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Meningiomas
  • Prolactinoma
  • Mesothelioma
  • Somatostatinoma.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old primigravida at 36 weeks gestation comes to the ER with nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Nausea and vomiting began one day back and now the patient is unable to tolerate fluids. She complains of pain in the right upper quadrant which started a few hours back. On examination, her temperature is 100.2 F, the pulse is 118 bpm and her BP is 110/70 mm of Hg. She has swelling of her lower limbs up to the ankles bilaterally. Abdominal examination shows a gravid uterus corresponding to 36 weeks of gestation and tenderness in the right upper quadrant, with mild guarding. She was treated for asymptomatic bacteriuria in the first trimester. Laboratory results are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Complete blood count

  • Hemoglobin: 11g/dL
  • Leukocytes: 13,000 cells/μL
  • Platelets: 150,000 cells/μL

Liver function tests

  • Aspartate transaminase (AST): 40U/L
  • Alanine transaminase (ALT): 48U/L

Urinalysis

  • Protein: negative
  • Pus cells: 1-2/HPF
  • Bacteria: none

USG Abdomen:

Reveals a 7mm diameter, aperistaltic, non-compressible, dilated, blind-ending structure arising from the base of the caecum
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical scenario along with the USG findings is most suggestive of acute appendicitis.

Acute appendicitis is the most common surgical non-gynecological cause of acute abdomen in pregnancy.

The diagnosis of acute appendicitis in pregnancy is difficult due to

  • Nausea and vomiting may be considered normal, especially in the first trimester of pregnancy
  • Leukocytosis is a physiological finding in pregnancy
  • A gravid enlarging uterus can push the appendix upward and outward, causing the pain to localize in the right flank or right upper quadrant.

Acute appendicitis in pregnancy is associated with miscarriage, preterm delivery, increased risk of peritonitis, perinatal and maternal mortality.

USG abdomen is used to confirm. MRI abdomen can be done if USG is inconclusive. Operative laparotomy with minimal uterine manipulation should be done at the earliest. Laparoscopic appendicectomy can be done before 28 weeks of gestation. USG Abdomen would reveal a >6mm diameter, aperistaltic, non-compressible, dilated appendix seen as a blind-ending structure arising from the base of the caecum

Other options:

Option B: Acute fatty liver of pregnancy also presents with nausea, vomiting, and right upper abdominal pain in the third trimester of pregnancy. However, it is associated with a significant elevation in liver transaminases, although usually <1000 U/L.

Option C: HELLP (hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, low platelets) syndrome, a complication of preeclampsia also presents with nausea and vomiting, with mid-epigastric pain. It is associated with proteinuria and platelet count <10,000 cells/μL.This patient's BP is normal and urinalysis shows no proteins. 

Option D: Acute pyelonephritis presents with nausea, vomiting, right flank pain, and spiking fever. Untreated asymptomatic bacteriuria in early pregnancy may increase the risk of acute pyelonephritis. This patient has a clean urinalysis, and no USG findings suggestive of pyelonephritis.

questions.text: You are evaluating a 7-year-old boy in the emergency department who was brought from school with complaints of fever and sore throat. On examination, he has extensive submandibular and cervical swelling. On performing an oral exam, he has foul breath and a well-demarcated white-gray exudative substance adherent to his oropharynx as shown in the image below. Attempts to remove this pseudomembranous substance result in bleeding. A rapid strep test on a throat swab is negative. On asking for the patient’s vaccination records, the school notes say that he has not undergone routine vaccinations by parental choice. Which of the following is incorrect about the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Systemic manifestations are due to bacterial toxin
Toxin acts by over-activating adenylate cyclase
The patient is at risk for congestive heart failure
Droplet precautions are recommended for the patient

questions.solution:
This is a classic clinical description and oral examination of a patient with diphtheria. The diphtheria toxin is an extremely potent protein toxin that acts by inhibiting protein synthesis by inactivating elongation factor (EF-2).

 Corynebacterium diphtheria (also called Klebs- Loeffler bacillus) is a gram-positive bacillus with clubbing at both ends. They possess characteristic polymetaphosphate granules also called metachromatic granules.  

Clinically, patients with diphtheria present with fever, sore throat, and pseudomembranous lesions on the tonsillar, pharyngeal, or nasal mucosa. The pseudo-membrane in diphtheria is tightly adherent to the underlying tissues and attempts to remove them result in bleeding. A few patients develop massive edema of the tonsils, submandibular and paratracheal region causing a characteristic bull-neck. It is associated with foul breath, thick speech, and stridor.

The systemic manifestations of diphtheria are due to diphtheria toxin and not due to bacteremia. It has a special affinity for myocardium, adrenal glands, and nerve endings and therefore, causes weakness as a result of neurotoxicity, cardiac arrhythmias, or congestive heart failure due to myocarditis.

Treatment of diphtheria includes administration of diphtheria anti-toxin. Recommended antibiotics include penicillin G and erythromycin for two weeks. Patients are placed in an isolation room and droplet precautions should be maintained for all cases of respiratory diphtheria. Although patients are not contagious starting 48 hours after antibiotic therapy, droplet precautions are typically maintained until the completion of antibiotic course and is culture-negative on two cultures taken 24 hours apart. Droplet precautions include use of masks, gowns, gloves and protective eye-gear when providing direct patient care. 

While the development of an effective vaccine has nearly eradicated the disease in many countries, failure to undergo routine vaccination leaves some patients at risk. Vaccination with diphtheria toxoid is recommended for all cases of diphtheria after convalescence, as natural infection may not induce an adequate level of protective immunity.

questions.text:
Use of raloxifene would be indicated for
  1. Treatment of osteoporosis in a 54-year-old post-menopausal female
  2. Prevention of osteoporosis in a 49-year-old post-menopausal female 
  3. Treatment of invasive breast cancer in a 39-year-old female
  4. Risk reduction for invasive breast cancer in a 56-year-old postmenopausal female with a family history of breast cancer
  5. Risk reduction for non-invasive breast cancer in a 48 year old perimenopausal female
questions.solution:
Use of raloxifene is not indicated for the treatment of invasive breast cancer or risk reduction for non-invasive breast cancer

Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM). 

  • It has an antagonist action on estrogen receptors in the breast and uterine endometrial tissue. It reduces breast cancer cell growth and endometrial proliferation.
  • It has an agonist action on estrogen receptors in bone, which causes inhibition of osteoclasts reducing the risk of osteoporosis.

Indications for raloxifene include

  • Treatment and prevention of osteoporosis in postmenopausal females.
  • Risk reduction for invasive breast cancer especially in postmenopausal females with osteoporosis or with a high risk for invasive breast cancer 

Raloxifene is not indicated for the treatment of invasive breast cancer or reduction of the risk of recurrence. It is also not indicated for the reduction of the risk of noninvasive breast cancer.

Side effects of raloxifene include hot flashes and increased risk of venous thromboembolism.

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

All of these cancers express ER.
  • HER2-positive cancers - 10% to 20% of tumors, which may either be ER-positive or ER-negative.
  • ER-negative, HER2-negative carcinomas (triple-negative or basal-like)- are characterized by genomic instability, a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (e.g., basal keratins).

questions.text: During dissection, the professor points to a structure in the popliteal fossa marked with the red arrow shown in the image below. He further mentions that damage to this structure would cause a high-stepping gait and an inability to dorsiflex the ankle. The structure marked is ______.
questions.solution:
The damaged structure is most likely a common peroneal nerve. It is also called the common fibular nerve. It descends down obliquely along the lateral side of the popliteal fossa till the fibular head. It lies medial to the biceps femoris.

The common peroneal nerve is a component of the sciatic nerve. In the posterior thigh, it supplies the short head of the biceps femoris. It curves around the neck of the fibula deep to the peroneus longus and divides into superficial and deep peroneal nerves.

  • The superficial peroneal nerve innervates peroneus longus and peroneus brevis which are the evertors of the foot and to the skin over the dorsal area of the foot except for the first webspace and lateral side of the little toe.
  • The deep peroneal nerve innervates all muscles of the anterior compartment which are the dorsiflexors of the foot, extensor digitorum brevis, first two dorsal interossei muscles, and skin between the great and second toes.

The common peroneal nerve is more prone to injury as it lies superficial at the level of the lateral aspect of the neck of the fibula. The clinical features of common peroneal nerve injury include the following:

  • Foot drop (as shown in the image below)
  • Weakness or paralysis of ankle dorsiflexion, toe extension, and eversion
  • A diminished sensation on the dorsum of the foot including the first dorsal web space
  • Plantar flexion, inversion, and ankle reflex are preserved

 

 

Other options:

Option B: Sural nerve is a terminal branch of the tibial nerve and the common fibular nerve. Damage to this nerve results in a diminished sensation of the posterior and lateral aspects of the distal third in the leg. In the foot, there is diminished sensation over the lateral malleolus and the lateral side of the fifth toe.

Option C: Saphenous nerve is the longest and largest cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve. Damage to this nerve results in a diminished sensation in the skin over the patella, medial side of the leg, and medial side of the foot.

Option D: Tibial nerve is a component of the sciatic nerve. It is derived from the anterior divisions of L4, L5, S1, S2, and S3. In the popliteal fossa, this nerve is overlapped by two heads of gastrocnemius. Damage to this nerve paralyzes gastrocnemius, plantaris, soleus, and popliteus muscles.

questions.text: Which part of the spine is most commonly affected in patients with rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
The atlantoaxial joint (C1 & C2) is the most commonly affected part of the spine in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

The joints in rheumatoid arthritis are bilaterally and symmetrically involved. The commonly affected joints are:

  • Metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints
  • Wrists
  • Proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints
  • Metatarsophalangeal joints (MTP) joints
  • Atlantoaxial joint

There is relative sparing of the DIP joint in rheumatoid arthritis. The involvement of DIP joints should direct suspicion towards osteoarthritis.

questions.text: A mother brings her 4-month-old female child to the outpatient department. She was delivered by C-section. The pregnancy was complicated by oligohydramnios and breech presentation. On examination of the child, you notice the finding shown in the image below. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
A Pavlik harness after closed reduction is the most appropriate management for this infant, with history and examination suggestive of developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). The image shows one knee (affected knee) at a lower level compared to the other, which is known as Galeazzi's sign.

Developmental dysplasia of the hip or congenital dysplasia of the hip is characterized by spontaneous dislocation of the hip joint before, during, or shortly after birth. Risk factors for DDH include-

  • Sex of the baby - Female gender is more susceptible 
  • Intrauterine positioning - Breech position 
  • Oligohydramnios
  • Genetic predisposition 

Examination of the developmental dysplasia of the hip-

  • Tests to check instability of the hip -
    • Ortolani test: To perform this test, the infant is supine, with the hip and knee flexed. With the thumb placed over the medial thigh and the index finger on the greater trochanter, the hip is gently abducted. This reduces the femoral head into the acetabulum producing a palpable "clunk". 
    • Barlow test: This test is done within 2–3 days of birth. To perform this test, the infant is supine with the knees fully flexed and the hip at 90° of flexion. Gentle adduction results in a posterior subluxation or dislocation of an easily dislocatable femoral head, producing a palpable "clunk"
  • Galeazzi's test is shown in the above image. It is done between 3 to 8-month aged children in unilateral cases of developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). To perform this test, the child is in the supine position with the hip and knee in flexion. The level of both the knee joints is noted with respect to a horizontal line. Normally both knees should be at the same level. In DDH, the affected knee is seen at a lower level indicating femoral shortening. This is also known as the Allis sign. 
  • Marked asymmetry of the inguinal, gluteal, thigh, or popliteal folds.
  • Decreased abduction on the affected side.
  • Positive tredelenburg sign
  • Limb-length discrepancy

Treatment of DDH includes early closed reduction with splinting or casts. If closed reduction cannot be achieved in long-standing dislocations, an open reduction may become necessary.

  • < 6 months: Closed reduction with Pavlik harness or Von Rosen splint is done.  
  • 6-18 months: Closed or open reduction with hip spica application is done.
  • 1.5 years- 3 years: Open reduction and pelvic or femoral osteotomies may be required
  • 3-8 years: Femoral shortening or pelvic osteotomies.
  • >8 years: Femoral and pelvic osteotomies or total hip replacement considered

Related Pearl: Age wise management of DDH

6-18 months Closed or open reduction followed by hip spica after reduction
18-36 months Open reduction with femoral shortening and pelvic osteotomy (Salter's osteotomy, Pemberton osteotomy, Steel osteotomy)

questions.text: A mother with polyhydramnios delivered a baby at term gestation. She was unable to feed the baby as it choked on the milk. She also noticed the baby's abdomen appeared distended. Vesicular breath sounds in bilateral lung fields and abdominal distension were noted on examination. An attempt to pass a nasogastric tube fails. An X-ray is ordered and appears as shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms of choking and abdominal distention with a failure to pass a nasogastric tube and an X-ray showing NG tube in proximal esophagus and stomach distended with gas suggests the presence of a tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF).

A tracheoesophageal fistula is an abnormal fistula communication between the esophagus and trachea. Among the different types, Type C is the most common type. It consists of proximal esophageal atresia and distal TEF. With each breath, the air enters the distal esophagus and the stomach causing gastric distention which presents as abdominal distention. 

Inability to pass a nasogastric (NG) tube is a crucial pointer in the diagnosis of esophageal atresia. 

Tracheoesophageal fistula is associated with VACTERL (vertebral, anorectal, cardiac, tracheal, esophageal, renal, and limb) anomalies.


Other options:

Option A - Foreign body in the trachea will present with decreased air entry bilaterally in the lungs and stridor.

Option B - Gastric volvulus may also be associated with abdominal distension and difficulty in passing the NG tube into the stomach. However, in this case, the tube is seen stuck in the proximal esophagus itself making the diagnosis of TEF more likely.

Option D - Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is usually left-sided and presents with respiratory distress. On examination, bowel sounds are heard in the chest field as abdominal contents herniate into the chest. There is a scaphoid abdomen rather than a distended abdomen as in this case.

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheo-esophageal Fistula/Esophageal Atresia

Abbreviations:

  • EA: Esophageal atresia
  • TEF: Tracheo-esophageal Fistula

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes with complaints of excessive daytime sleepiness. His wife says he snores a lot. His BMI is 32, blood pressure- 156/100 mm Hg. He scored 12 on the Epworth scale. Muller maneuver suggested airway obstruction. He was advised to lose weight and to use an APAP machine for his symptoms. This machine helps improve his condition by providing:

choices.text: Continuous adjustment of positive airway pressure
Fixed negative pressure during inspiration and expiration
Higher pressure during inspiration and lower pressure during expiration
Lower pressure during inspiration and higher pressure during expiration

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests the diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnoea. APAP machine (Autotitrating continuous positive airway pressure) used for this condition acts by providing continuous adjustment of the airway pressure.

The symptoms of daytime somnolence, systemic hypertension, and a high BMI are indicative of obstructive sleep apnoea (OSA). OSA causes hypoventilation and resulting transient hypoxia and hypercapnia. Epworth scale is used to assess daytime sleepiness. A score of more than 10 is considered excessive daytime sleepiness. Muller maneuver is used to assess airway obstruction using a flexible endoscope. 

OSA is managed by providing positive airway pressure to maintain the airway during sleep. The following machines can be used:

  • CPAP (Continuous positive airway pressure) - It maintains the same level of air pressure during inspiration and expiration. 
  • BiPAP (Bilevel positive airway pressure) - It delivers a higher pressure during inspiration and a lower pressure during expiration.
  • APAP (Autotitrating continuous positive airway pressure) - It continuously adjusts the airway pressure.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man who has come for his health checkup enquires about a swelling in his left forearm. He had noticed it by chance 3 years ago. The swelling is not painful but has slightly increased in size. On examination, a firm, round, mobile mass is detected on the flexor aspect of his left forearm. There were no associated paresthesias or neurological deficits. The skin over the swelling and in the surrounding areas appears normal. Histopathological examination revealed the mass to be a schwannoma. Which among the following is false about the diagnosis?

choices.text: Antoni B areas are nuclear-free zones between areas of nuclear palisading
Antoni A areas are dense eosinophilic areas containing spindle cells
It involves loss of expression of the gene product Merlin
Schwannomas lacking Antoni B areas mimic sarcomas

questions.solution:
The false statement is option A. Nuclear-free zones lying between the regions of nuclear palisading are known as Verocay bodies.

Schwannomas are noninvasive, well-circumscribed, and encapsulated tumors that arise from the Schwann cells of the peripheral nerve sheaths. It occurs due to loss of expression of merlin - an NF2 gene product. Merlin normally restricts the expression of growth factor receptors like EGFR on the cell surface. In its absence, cells hyperproliferate in response to growth factors.

It presents as a slow-growing, painless mass, with a predilection for flexor surfaces of the forearm and palm. They are usually solitary, but patients with NF 1 or NF2 may develop multiple schwannomas involving large peripheral nerves or bilateral acoustic schwannomas.

Paraesthesias and neurological findings are usually absent, but can rarely occur if the tumor compresses the nerve or undergoes malignant change. 

Pathological Features:

Gross - They appear as firm, grey masses. 

Microscopic - Schwann cells are spindle-shaped cells containing a wavy or buckled shape nucleus. Schwannomas consist of a mixture of Antoni A and Antoni B areas. 

  • Antoni A areas are dense eosinophilic areas containing spindle-shaped cells. These cells are arranged as intersecting fascicles and nuclear palisading is seen here. The nuclear-free zones between the palisading are termed as Verocay bodies.
  • Antoni B areas are loose hypocellular areas, where the spindle cells are spread apart by the myxoid extracellular matrix. 
  • Some large mitotically active Schwannomas lacking Antoni B areas can mimic a sarcoma. 

 

 

Treatment - Symptomatic tumors are surgically resected.

questions.text: An elderly man presents for evaluation following an episode of syncope the same day. He reports having fatigue, chest pain, and exertional breathlessness. 2D-echo shows left ventricular hypertrophy, with an aortic valve area of 0.8 sq. cm. What will be the character of the pulse in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical scenario is suggestive of aortic stenosis (AS), which is associated with the characteristic pulsus parvus et tardus.

Aortic stenosis is the narrowing of the aortic valve. It may be caused by the calcification of the normal aortic valve, calcification of the congenital bicuspid valve, and rheumatic heart disease. Narrowing of the aortic valve causes a decreased stroke volume. This results in a weak pulse (parvus), which rises slowly to a delayed peak (tardus), best appreciated in the carotid arteries.

Three cardinal clinical features of aortic stenosis:

  • Exertional dyspnea: This occurs due to left ventricular (LV) diastolic dysfunction. Raised end-diastolic LV volume and reduced LV compliance lead to increased LV pressure, leading to elevation of pulmonary capillary wedge pressure. This causes exertional dyspnea.
  • Angina pectoris: It occurs due to the combination of the increased O2 needs of hypertrophied myocardium and reduction of O2 delivery 
  • Syncope: It occurs due to the combination of decreased cardiac output and systemic arterial dilation which lead to a reduction of cerebral perfusion.

As LV systole gets prolonged, the aortic component of S2 may become synchronous with the pulmonary component, or there may be a paradoxical splitting of S2, where the aortic component follows the pulmonary component. The murmur in aortic stenosis is typically an ejection systolic murmur best heard at the right second intercostal space and transmitted to the carotids. 

Severe AS is defined as the aortic valve area <1 cm2. Patients even with severe AS may be asymptomatic as the left ventricle undergoes hypertrophy to increase the intraventricular pressure and maintain the stroke volume. Symptomatic AS is an indication for valve replacement.

Other options:

Option A: Pulsus alternans is defined as beat-to-beat variability in the amplitude of the pulse. It is seen in patients with severe LV dysfunction.

Option B: Pulsus bisferiens also known as bifid pulse has two systolic peaks. It is seen in patients with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy. There is a rapid upstroke to the first peak (percussion wave) and a slower rise to the second peak (tidal wave). It is also rarely appreciated in patients with severe aortic regurgitation.

Option C: Pulsus paradoxus is defined as a fall in systolic pressure >10 mmHg with inspiration. It is seen in patients with pericardial tamponade, severe asthma, massive pulmonary embolism, and tension pneumothorax.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the difference in the incidence of asthma in children who are exposed to second-hand smoke and those who are not. If he wishes to express the additional incidence of asthma in the exposed children as a percentage, which of the following should he use?
questions.solution:
The researcher may use attributable risk to express the increased incidence of asthma in the exposed children.

Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates of disease (or death) between an exposed group and the non-exposed group. It is often expressed as a percentage. The terms "risk difference" or "cumulative incidence difference" refers to attributable risk.

Other Options:

Option B: Relative risk (RR) is the ratio of the incidence of the disease (or death) among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed.

Option C: Population-attributable risk is the incidence of the disease (or death) in the total population minus the incidence of disease (or death) among those who were not exposed to the suspected causal factor. Population attributable risk is measured by multiplying attributable risk with the population prevalence of exposure.

Option D: Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between a risk factor and outcome in case-control studies.

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where,

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

Related Pearl: Odds Ratio

  • Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between risk factor and outcome in case control studies.
  • Odds ratio can be arrived at from case control studies.

  • OR = 1 indicates no association of risk with exposure, or that the event is equally likely in both groups.
  • OR > 1 indicates increased risk (positive association) as the frequency of exposure is greater among cases than controls.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with burns was brought to the casualty department. As shown in the image below, there was sparing of the front and back of the chest and face. Painful erythema was present on both palms.  Also, there was uniform involvement of both lower limbs circumferentially, genitalia, and the front and back of the abdomen. Lesions were painful and showed blanching on pressure. What fluid resuscitation plan would you choose as per the 2018 ATLS guidelines, if the patient weighed 50 kg?

choices.text: 2.75 L over 8 hours, followed by 2.75 L over 16 hours
4.5 L over 8 hours, followed by 4.5 L over 16 hours
6 L over 8 hours, followed by 6 L over 16 hours
9 L over 8 hours, followed by 9 L over 16 hours

questions.solution:
The given image shows second-degree burns, as evident from the moist appearance of the skin, associated with pain and blanching on pressure. The total volume of fluid needed is 5.5 L, of which 2.75 L is given in the first 8 hours and 2.75L is given in the next 16 hours as indicated by 

Step 1: Calculating the percentage of burns using the Wallace rule of nines:

  • This includes only second- and third-degree burns.
  • Right lower limb + left lower limb and anterior-posterior lower torso + genitalia = 18 + 18 + 18 + 1 = 55%

STEP 2: Calculating fluid using the resuscitation formula for thermal burns:

According to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines, the fluid resuscitation formula for thermal burns is 2 mL/kg/TBSA% given IV.

Fluid requirement = 2 mL x body weight x TBSA

                          = 2 mL x 50 kg x 55%

                          = 5.5 L

One-half of the calculated fluid need is given in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is given over the subsequent 16 hours.

The rate of infusion for IV resuscitation fluid should be as constant as possible; sharp decreases in infusion rates can lead to vascular collapse and an increase in edema.

Superficial (epidermal) burns are excluded from this calculation.

According to the depth and the extent of tissue damage, burn injuries can be classified into three degrees:

  • First-degree burns: There is damage to the epidermis. These injuries are extremely painful but do not blister. Capillary refilling time remains normal.
  • Second-degree burns (partial-thickness burns): There is damage to the epidermis and dermis. Depending on the extent of the dermal involvement, they can further be divided as follows:
    • Superficial partial-thickness burns: They involve the epidermis and upper part of the dermis (papillary). These injuries are red, moist, and extremely painful, with blisters. Capillary return is clearly visible when the injured skin is blanched.
    • Deep partial-thickness burns: They involve the epidermis and the deeper dermis. These injuries are less painful and some sensation is preserved. The capillaries do not blanch on pressure.
  • Third-degree burns: There is damage to the epidermis, dermis, and subcutaneous tissue. The injuries have a hard leathery feel with the absence of sensation.
  • Fourth-degree burns: There is damage to the underlying soft tissues.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children.

  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text: A 28-year-old recently married woman was brought dead to the casualty with severe third-degree burns. An autopsy was conducted and chemical analysis revealed traces of kerosene on her clothes. An interrogation revealed there were frequent quarrels at home as her husband and his family constantly berated her for not bringing in money from her parents. Which of the following sections covers the punishment for this incident?
questions.solution:
This incident can be considered as dowry death which is defined under section 304B IPC.

When there is the death of a woman within 7 years of her marriage and she was subjected to cruelty or harassment by her husband or his family in demand of dowry, the husband/family member shall be deemed to have caused her death. The punishment for such cases is imprisonment for a minimum of 7 years, but may be extended to life imprisonment.

Option A: Section 304A IPC: Causing death by negligence (up to 2 yrs of imprisonment or fine or both).

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic patient presented with asymmetric pupils. On examination the degree of asymmetry was more in dim light. It was also associated with ptosis in the eye with the smaller pupil. Which of the following drugs can be used for the confirmation of diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of ptosis and anisocoria (asymmetric pupils) that is more apparent in dim light is suggestive of Horner’s syndrome. Apraclonidine drops can be used for the confirmation of Horner’s syndrome.

Horner syndrome, also called oculosympathetic paresis, is characterized by

  • Ptosis - usually due to weakness of Muller’s muscle
  • Miosis - due to unopposed action of sphincter pupillae leading to anisocoria
  • Anhydrosis - reduced ipsilateral sweating
  • Heterochromia iridis- seen in congenital and long-standing disease. The affected eye is lighter in color. 
  • Anisocoria that is accentuated in dim light

It can be produced by a lesion anywhere along the sympathetic pathway that supplies the head, eye, and neck.

Tests for confirmation of Horner's syndrome -

  • Apraclonidine drops - The results are 
    • Horner pupil dilates - due to upregulation of α1 receptors in the dilator pupillae. 
    • Normal pupil does not dilate
  • Cocaine drops 
    • Horner pupil does not dilate
    • Normal pupil dilates
    • This is because cocaine blocks the re-uptake of noradrenaline at the postganglionic nerve endings. This causes dilatation in a normal pupil. In Horner's syndrome, noradrenaline is not secreted. Therefore, the administration of cocaine has no effect.

Tests for localization of the lesion -

  • Phenylephrine or adrenaline
    • Postganglionic lesion - Horner pupil will dilate
    • Preganglionic and central lesions - pupil will not dilate
    • Normal pupil will not dilate
  • Hydroxyamphetamine
    • Preganglionic lesion - pupil will dilate
    • Postganglionic lesion - pupil will not dilate
    • Normal pupil will dilate

Other options

Option D - Pilocarpine is used in the differential diagnosis of fixed dilated pupils. Mydriasis due to neurologic origin (3rd nerve palsy) responds readily to 1% pilocarpine, whereas there will be no response if the dilation is due to anticholinergic causes.

Related Pearl: Horner's syndrome

Horner's Syndrome:

Horner's syndrome occurring due to occulo-sympathetic paresis is characterized by the classic triad of:

  • Mild ptosis (due to paralysis of Muller's muscle).
  • Miosis (due to paralysis of dilator pupillae).
  • Reduced ipsilateral sweating (anhydrosis).

Other features include:

  • Mild enophthalmos,
  • Loss of cilio-spinal reflex,
  • Heterochromia, i.e., the ipsilateral iris is lighter in colour,
  • Pupil is slow to dilate, and there occurs slight elevation of lower eyelid.

Cocaine test (2% to 4%): Small pupils fail to dilate in Horner's syndrome.

In congenital Horner's syndrome, the additional features seen are heterochromia iridis and unilateral straight hair.

questions.text: A 6-month-old is brought by his parents with a history of decreased weight gain. On examination, you find that the baby has hepatosplenomegaly, muscle weakness and atrophy, hypotonia, and decreased deep tendon reflexes. Blood tests reveal normal glucose levels. Biopsy of the liver reveals initial stages of cirrhosis due to the accumulation of abnormal glycogen with few branch points, whose structure resembles amylopectin. The clinical and laboratory results are indicative of which glycogen storage disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical and laboratory features indicate Andersen's disease in the baby. Inability to gain weight, hepatosplenomegaly, muscle weakness, and accumulation of abnormal glycogen resembling amylopectin point towards the diagnosis.

Andersen's disease is type IV glycogen storage disease. It is transmitted in an autosomal recessive pattern and occurs due to a deficiency of glycogen branching enzyme because of pathologic variants in the GBE1 gene. This leads to accumulation of of an abnormal structure of glycogen known as polyglucosan.  It is characterized by

  • Growth delay
  • Hepatomegaly due to the accumulation of polysaccharides with few branch points
  • Myopathy
  • There might be fasting intolerance and ketosis in the initial stages. Hypoglycemia usually appears late in the disease when it is associated with cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and ascites. 
  • Biopsy of the liver will show the presence of abnormal glycogen which resembles amylopectin. Amylopectin is found in plants and has very few branches. Since there is a defect in the branching of the glycogen, the abnormal glycogen appears like amylopectin.

The diagnosis is confirmed by absent branching enzyme activity in skin fibroblasts, muscle, or liver and analysis of the DNA mutation.

Other options

Option A- Von Gierke's disease has features of lactic acidosis, hypoglycemia, hyperuricemia, impaired growth, and bone thinning. It occurs due to a defect in the glucose 6-phosphatase.

Option C- McArdle disease usually manifests as exercise intolerance, muscle cramping with exercise. It is usually a benign chronic condition. It occurs due to a defect in the muscle glycogen phosphorylase.

Option D- Tarui disease also presents similar to the McArdle disease. Patients may have developmental delay, and hemolytic anemia in addition to exercise-induced muscle cramps. It occurs due to a defect in the muscle phosphofructokinase.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient attends your clinic for health check-up. He says that he does not have any friends and does not like to go out often. He lives by himself. Throughout the examination, he does not make eye-contact. He seems quiet for the most part and answers your questions with a single word or phrase. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of schizoid personality disorder.

It is a cluster A personality disorder that includes-

  • Paranoid personality disorder
  • Schizoid personality disorder
  • Schizotypal personality disorder.

Schizoid personality disorder is characterized by a tendency for social withdrawal, isolation, and introversion. They tend to live alone and take up jobs that require minimal interpersonal interaction. They are emotionally detached, aloof, and have a flattened affect. They avoid eye contact and conversations and when questioned, are likely to give short direct responses. They do not desire relationships or sexual intimacy and tend not to have partners or friends. However, they have a good attachment with animals. They also tend to have solitary hobbies and interests. 

Other options-

Option A- Paranoid personality disorder is characterized by pervasive suspiciousness and mistrust in all interpersonal relationships. They are excessively fearful about perceived threats and deceit. They tend to be extremely jealous and hostile, argumentative, and defensive. A commonly seen defense mechanism is projection. 

Option B- Avoidant personality disorder is characterized by isolation but a strong wish to participate in activities and relationships. This is absent in those with schizoid personality disor­der where people do not desire social interaction and relationships. 

Option C- Schizotypal personality disorder is characterized by odd perceptions, thinking, and behavior. They tend to have magical thinking, bizarre fantasies, and preoccupations, such as excessive superstition, and beliefs that they have superpowers, etc. They have peculiar speech and an eccentric appearance. They can be differentiated from schizophrenia by the lack of psychotic features.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of hypertension and prior MI was found to have raised total cholesterol and LDL and was started on simvastatin. Which would be the best time for him to take this drug so as to have an optimum effect on his LDL levels?

choices.text: It is equally effective irrespective of the time of administration

questions.solution:
Simvastatin demonstrates a significant LDL-C (low-density lipoprotein cholesterol) reduction when administered in the evening, compared with morning administration.

For statins with shorter half-lives like lovastatin 2 hours, simvastatin < 5 hours, and fluvastatin < 3 hours, the FDA has recommended an evening administration, while daytime administration is recommended for statins with longer half-lives like rosuvastatin 19 hours, and pravastatin 22 hours.

Atorvastatin has active metabolites with half-lives ranging from 20 to 30 hours, which may contribute to the fact that it can be taken at any time, and demonstrates the same LDL-C reduction regardless of the time of day of drug administration.

questions.text: A patient presented to a primary care physician with complaints of depression. She takes a monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitor. The physician added another anti-depressant following which she developed restlessness, fever, extreme agitation with hyperreflexia, and autonomic instability. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be added?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient who is on a Monoamine Oxidase (MAO) develops diarrhea, restlessness, fever, extreme agitation with hyperreflexia, and autonomic instability which is suggestive of serotonin syndrome. The newly added drug must have been a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). Among the given options, fluoxetine is an SSRI.

When an SSRI is administered along with an MAO-I, tramadol, and pethidine, plasma levels of serotonin are raised resulting in serotonin syndrome. Clinical features of serotonin syndrome include diarrhea, agitation, restlessness, rigidity, hyperthermia, hyperreflexia, autonomic instability, twitchings followed by convulsions, delirium, coma, status epilepticus, cardio­ vascular collapse, and death.

Treatment involves removing the offending agent and supportive care. 

Other options:

Option B: Imipramine is a tricyclic antidepressant. Common side effects include anticholinergic symptoms, sedation, weight gain, and cardiac arrhythmias. TCAs given with MAO inhibitors can result in hypertensive crisis with excitement and hallucinations.

Option C: Mirtazapine acts by enhancing noradrenaline and 5-HT release. It helps patients with insomnia. Common side effects include increased appetite and weight gain. It doesn't cause sexual dysfunction.

Option D: Trazadone is also an atypical antidepressant. Common side effects include postural hypotension and priapism.
